claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers a potent type I interferon response.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors

claims.caveat: The observed effects were in murine models and may not directly translate to all human tumors.

claims.claim: The vaccine-induced inflammation improves antigen presentation on tumor cells.

evidence.quote: Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.
Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination sensitizes tumors to PD-L1 blockade.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, limiting direct causal claims about sensitization.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in patients receiving ICI.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely. Vaccination timing and tumor heterogeneity are major limitations.
